news uk-news drivers-can-clear-ice-frost-"Woman’s clever towel hack will stop your car windscreen freezing overnightByBenjamin LynchSEO Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsMotorists can expect problems with ice even as the days start to grow a little bit longer into . The temperature is set to dip this week and people could wake up to cars with frozen windscreens. A spokesman for the Met Office said: It will turn very briefly colder on Thursday and as conditions move south it will bring showers with it.Thankfully, a simple solution can help you clear ice from the windscreen of your car quickly. Scraping away while you need to rush to work, or speed the kids off to school, is an annoying task that can be less than ideal for the morning madness.So, how can you get rid of ice on your windscreen easily with minimal products and time spent doing so  How to clear ice and frost off windscreens easily using one ingredient  You only need one easily bought ingredients to clear your windscreen of ice - rubbing alcohol mixed with water. Thataposs right, the experts at Nationwide Vehicle Contracts revealed that mixing the solution together in a spray bottle should do the trick. Rubbing alcohol can be bought from most of the big supermarkets or pharmacies like Superdrug and Boots, and it should set you back around £. Nationwide Vehicle Contracts said: Mix one part water with two parts rubbing alcohol and fill the spray bottle with the solution. This can then be sprayed on your windscreen to melt the ice.  What’s best is that this solution will not freeze, as rubbing alcohol has a freezing point of around -C, which means the bottle can be kept in your car until next time. Alcohol brings down the freezing temperature of water, which is what makes this trick so useful. Sciencing explained: As the required freezing temperature drops when alcohol is added to ice, the temperature of the glass or where surrounding the ice is now higher than the new freezing point.Since itaposs no longer cold enough to stay frozen, the ice melts. Three other safe and easy tips for de-icing your windscreen quickly  There are plenty of ways you can make sure you donapost have the problem of having to spend time scraping away ice from your car first thing in the morning. Switch on the engine to de-ice and de-mist your windscreen Small warning: this solution isnapost great for the environment, but as your car warms up the ice should melt pretty quickly. Turn your heat up and use the setting that activates the air vent for your windscreen, then give it time to thaw. The AA advises staying with your car the whole time the engine is running and also turning on the air conditioning. This will remove moisture from the air to stop the screen misting up.If the screen does mist up, use a cloth to clear it and not your hand.De-ice your windscreen with water Use lukewarm water, but do not use boiling water. Boiling water can cause a quick temperature change that can cause your windscreen to crack.  Autoglass advised: You will find that the amount of water required will depend on the size of the windshield or rear window that needs defrosting.Apply the warmed water to the frozen area by pouring or splashing it directly onto your windscreen. Vinegar solutions can de-ice your windscreen Use a solution of white vinegar mixed with water as a form of de-icing spray. There are plenty of de-icing sprays on the market, but this mixture works as well. Plus, itaposs cheap and easy to find the key ingredient as youaposre likely to have white vinegar in your kitchen cupboard. You should mix two thirds white vinegar with one third water. Spray this on the windshield the night before as the temperature drops. This should prevent your windscreen from icing up in the first place. title: grans flat cold grandkids visit
story: Picture by Tim Merry" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _JS.jpg" width"" "" Grandmother Diane Skidmore’s flat is so cold her grandchildren can’t even visit Image: Tim MerryByLucy ThorntonNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsGrandmother Diane Skidmore’s flat is so bitterly cold her grandchildren can’t even visit. The -year-old admits her home leaves all her visitors shivering and her family worried she’ll get pneumonia. But Diane says these are the s she has to go, to keep those rising energy bills down. The mum-of-six and gran to seven, has seen her energy bills soar by % in recent months from £ to £. Speaking from her frosty ground floor flat in Tulse Hill, South London, she said: “A neighbour came in yesterday and I noticed she was shivering. “I said ‘I’m really sorry. Let’s move into the living room’, where the temperature was not much dferent but the sun was shining in.” The Mirror is calling for VAT on energy bills to be scrapped as rocketing prices look set to push millions into poverty. Former NHS worker Diane gets £ to live on after her rent is paid from her state pension and is dreading the energy bill rises to come.“I live in the cold. My hands are freezing at the moment. Quite often my nose is cold like a dog’s. My kids are worried I will get pneumonia. “My daughters won’t bring the kids around because my house is so cold. They worry about me getting diseases or stuff too. “ Since the pandemic Diane only ventures out to get her prescriptions because she is asthmatic and has been shielding so does not spend any money on luxuries. “I’m very worried the bills are going up because I can’t live any more frugally than I already live,” she explained. “I already don’t turn the heating on most days and I never ever turn the heating on at night. “On the very coldest days I put it on at pm and put the kitchen timer on for half an hour. There is a cold patch around about pm. “I’ve got a bath but I don’t do that a lot to be honest. I’m very low maintenance. “I mostly eat vegetables. I’ve got a gas kettle because electric kettles take up so much energy. “I’m just worried it’s going to be horrible. I have to have faith. I’m not the only one with trouble going on, they have to come up with a solution.”  Diane says she has tried other ways to heat her flat by blocking all the air vents and putting a big thick heavy curtain up but said it just causes condensation and black mould. “But I refuse to moan about it because when I was young we didn’t have gas central heating, when it got cold you just put a jumper on or do some exercise,” she said. But then admits: “At night it is very cold in here. “At the moment it’s only one degree at night and I can feel my head and my nose are absolutely verging on damp. I have to go down the bed under the sheets to get warm. “My old neighbour, who died, had a ‘noddy’ hat which he kept on all through winter. He used to sleep in it too. “Maybe I should get a hat.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSPensionsEnergy billsState pension" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: ive spent 20000 travelling abroad
story: Exclusive: Ive spent £, travelling abroad for Long Covid treatment as UK lags behindFitness fanatic Ronan Boyle, , has twice travelled to Germany for treatment as he believes the UK has fallen behind, but said most Long Covid sufferers are unable to do soRonan Boyle has twice travelled to Germany for Long Covid treatment, saying the UK is lagging behind Image: Ronan BoyleByDave BurkeSenior News Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA super-fit sports fanatic who has fought a two year battle with Long Covid has spent nearly £, travelling abroad for treatment - claiming the UK is lagging dangerously behind.Ronan Boyle, , used to run triathlons and spent days kayaking before he contracted coronavirus at the start of the pandemic back in March .Since then he has been unable to do the activities he loves and can only work part time due to the debilitating long-term impact. In desperation for a way out of his two-year nightmare, he twice travelled to Germany for groundbreaking treatment to remove tiny blood clots, which some scientists believe are potentially to blame for Long Covid symptoms.Ronan has called on the NHS to roll out testing and carry out trials on apheresis treatment - which removes harmful components in a patientaposs blood - as most sufferers are financially or physically unable to go to clinics abroad.However UKaposs National Institute for Health and Care Excellence says it has no plans to introduce the treatment and claims to have seen little evidence that microclots are the cause for symptoms.  Ronan warns that frustrated patients are turning to the internet to find treatment as a result. Ronan, from Belfast, told The Mirror: Itaposs really really expensive, Iaposve had  sessions and Iaposve burned through nearly £,, but for an awful lot of people that would be completely out of the question. At the moment weaposve got people flying to Germany, and others flying to South Africa for treatment. Weaposve got people trying to source medication themselves, and thataposs a disaster zone. We have . million people living in the UK with a disease thataposs potentially treatable, we should be shouting about that. A study from South Africa has suggested that many Long Covid patients develop microclots in their blood, which could be responsible for the exhaustion and breathlessness they experience. And British respiratory consultant Dr Asad Khan, himself a Long Covid sufferer since , has had the treatment overseas himself after becoming frustrated with trying to have it dealt with here.  When Ronan - who had to travel in a wheelchair - was first treated in Kempten, Germany, in September, he said his blood blocked a filter machine with what he believes were tiny clots. He immediately found one of his worse symptoms, insomnia, had improved, but ed to Germany weeks later when his condition started to regress and was given a three-month course of medication to treat clotting. Thereaposs more and more data pointing to microclots being responsible for Long Covid. Whether thataposs the full picture or part of the picture we donapost yet know, but itaposs certainly in the picture, he said. Letaposs start doing something. Itaposs very frustrating for people to see this research and not being able to get this treatment. The IT consultant, whose weight dropped to under  stone in  as he battled the condition, said enduring Long Covid has been a massive struggle. Itaposs an awful disease, itaposs so brutal, he said. I was pretty much wasting away. And we donapost know what longterm damage itaposs doing. Youaposre waiting for your le to start again, itaposs like your le is on hold. For me the first  months were hell. I had horric insomnia, fatigue, I was told I needed anti-depressant medication but that didnapost do a thing. I wasnapost sleeping, I wasnapost able to work. Everything is a hurdle, I had to use a wheelchair to get through the airport, thereaposs no way Iaposd have been able to walk through. The thing that keeps me going is that Iaposm doing something about it and being proactive, Iaposll keep doing what I can. Scientists have called for more research into whether blood clotting is responsible for patients enduring symptoms so long after Covid infection.A study led by Prof Resia Pretorius, who heads the physiological sciences department at Stellenbosch University in South Africa, found evidence that people with Covid are likely to develop tiny blood clots.Prof Pretorius has said there is a need for more research to provide further understanding of the link between blood clotting and Long Covid. Michael MacLennan, chief executive of charity Covid:aid, told The Mirror that he is aware of more people travelling abroad for microclotting treatment. Itaposs something weaposve been aware of, especially with more publicity surrounding the work of Professor Resia Pretorius and her lab, he said. Long Covid has caused untold and long-lasting misery since March April  for thousands across the UK, with well over a million suffering for persistent symptoms. In the UK we need to be exploring any and all research which displays promise to alleviate those afflicted. And he said that people suffering with the effects of Long Covid are often having their condition dismissed. Mr MacLennan said: At covid:aid weaposve consistently heard of experiences where people with very real physical experiences as a result of Long Covid have been gaslit and told itaposs aposin their headapos – unfortunately including from medical professionals. More awareness and training is desperately needed so people with Long Covid can receive the treatment they need, and not experience stigma in addition to the traumas they are already experiencing. However the UKaposs National Institute for Health and Care Excellencesaid it has no plans to introduce the treatment. A spokesman said: We are not aware of the research you mention and do not have any work in progress to update our guidance on long COVID given that the only evidence we’ve found through our ongoing surveillance is an opinion piece, which wouldn’t be sufficient for us to conduct a review of evidence in this area. We’ve also been unable to find anything signicant on microclotting as a cause of symptoms. We continue to monitor the emergence of new evidence around the treatment of long COVID and regularly update our guidance to reflect this. title: i wash kids hair cider
story: I wash my kids hair with cider vinegar instead of shampoo and limit the toys we buyJagroop Sahi says it took a while to get it right so her children did not just go around smelling of fish and chips but her familys lestyle changes have given them a dferent perspectiveJagroop Sahi wanted the best for her children Image: Jagroop SahiByRachael DavisJoseph WilkesProduction editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A mum has revealed how she washed her kidsapos hair with apple cider vinegar and avoids buying them plastic toys in an effort to overhaul her familyaposs lestyle and help the planet.Jagroop Sahi, , began making massive changes after her first child Arvaya was born a little over four years ago. She began by removing harsh chemicals and toxins from her daily routines to help give her unborn daughter the best start in le and instead focused on organic, natural and sustainable products and practices. She changed her approach to everything from skincare and haircare to food, toys and even nappies. Now a parent to two children - four-year-old Arvaya and seven-month-old Sienna - with husband Amar, Jagroop admits it took a while to get everything right. Have you got in interesting story to tell  Email webnews@mirror She told MyLondon : We tried the aposno shampoo movementapos, we use coconut oil and apple cider vinegar with essential oils as shampoo. Iaposm the only one in the family who isnapost free of shampoo, but Iaposve moved to shampoo bars instead.At the beginning of giving everyone vinegar as shampoo, that was atrocious, because my daughter used go swimming and her and my husband would go into the pool and just stink of vinegar. It took a while to get the essential oil concentration to vinegar [ratio] correct, so that they donapost just go around smelling of fish and chips. Jagroop and her family all use coconut oil instead of moisturiser, which she says has saved a fortune.  And they have experimented with things like cloth nappies for the baby and silicone kitchen sponges. The Sahi family also try to reduce the amount of toys they buy and find sturdier playthings. And they work to repair existing toys. We try not to buy plastic toys, Jagroop said, but sustainability is actually about trying to reduce your wastage:something breaks,you can fix that thing, it doesnapost matter that itaposs plastic. If you canapost, give it to someone  who could fix it, try to keep it in the loop without it going in the bin. When youaposre throwing something away itaposs going somewhere, itaposs either ended up landfill, itaposs ended up in the ocean, it ends up somewhere. So, letaposs try and keep things in the cycle without bringing in too many unnecessary new things.  Not everything has worked - like with the apple cider vinegar shampoo, it can be a lot of trial and error - and Jagroop says one of the biggest mistakes she made at the beginning was trying to do too much too quickly. In the beginning, I got overwhelmed, she said. We went vegan, we did everything [at once], and we stopped after two weeks. Sustainability is really hard actually, it can be, and I thinkyou try and do it all in one go, it can be really overwhelming. Thataposs the biggest lesson I learned. With my first child I tried to do the cloth nappies, full bang, and it didnapost work. But this time around Iaposve tried the cloth nappies again, but weaposre doing it really slowly. Weaposre changing just one a day to a cloth nappy, two a day, three a day. Weaposre not completely perfect. But the number of nappies you do save, even by making that switch a couple of times a day, makes such a big dference. But now we donapost really feel it, because you donapost feel like youaposre ever losing anything, youaposre just swapping it out for more sustainable products.  After spending many years living in London, with Amar having grown up in Harrow, the family moved to the village of Great Missenden in Buckinghamshire to bring up their kids in the countryside and get the best of both worlds. They get a big open field, and then youaposre so close to London - itaposs just a short drive in, she added. In terms of the financial impact of sustainable living, Jagroop says that things kind of balance each other out. Where a product like a big tub of cold pressed, raw coconut oil might seem expensive, the family gets its moneyaposs worth by using it as shampoo and moisturiser, among other things. The cost of her organic food shop has definitely got more expensive in recent months but she puts this down to high rates of inflation. Jagroop says living a more sustainable, mindful lestyle translates into the way she goes about her day-to-day le and raises her kids. It started to give us a dferent perspective, she said. As we started to get more and more into our sustainable journey, and started to do things our own way, we started to look at that in our parenting as well. Slowly, slowly, we started to adopt these approaches - like gentle parenting, attachment parenting, Montessori education, giving them independence. Because we had a similar approach to sustainability, likeitaposs not working for you, letaposs change something, learn as you go, it kind of made us realise that we as parents are still learning, we donapost know everything. Letaposs start being open and honest about that with our children and show them that actually, you know, even at this age, you donapost know everything. Weaposre all learning, just the same way we have with sustainability. If you make a mistake, donapost worry about it, apologise, learn from it, and then try and be better. title: miracle baby weighed same tin
story: Miracle baby weighed same as a tin of tomatoes after being born at just  weeksKimberley Byers and husband Glenn, revealed it has been "quite a journey" for Rory who has battled through a bowel infection,  blood transfusions and the antibiotic-resistant MRSA bugRory Byers was born at just  weeks Image: Kimberly Byers  SWNSByAshley SummerfieldGraeme Murray:,  Jan | commentsA miracle baby who was born at  weeks weighed the same as a tin of tomatoes. His mother Kimberley Byers had a C-section to allow him to come into the world.The -year-old gave birth to baby Rory in June and he was four months premature when he arrived.She was overjoyed and said: He arrived + weeks early!!! Weighing g which is a tin and a half of tomatoes! But she is now worried her maternity pay will end before her son leaves hospital. Rory who has has aged seven months, weighed just  grams when he was born, but doctors still do not think he is fit to go home.She and husband Glenn, , said that it has been quite a journey for Rory who has battled through a bowel infection,  blood transfusions and the antibiotic-resistant MRSA bug. But Rory, who has a three-year-old brother called Zak, powered through much to his parentsapos joy.Kimberly of St Neots, Cambridgeshire told WalesOnline : He is such an inspiration – itaposs been quite a journey.“We have watched him almost die several times.” But Kimberly has voiced her pain at living  miles from her baby - who is still being treated in hospital.  The mum-of-two has to travel  miles every day to Addenbrookeaposs Hospital, Cambridge, and with her maternity pay due to end in eight weeks, she is worried Rory will still be in hospital. This leaves her with the dilemma of ing to work as a nanny or running out of money. Her husband Glenn works as a sales manager. Kimberly said: How can I go back to work when my child is in hospital still   If I knew we had  weeks of paid then we could still cover our bills. Kimberlyaposs friends are also fundraising to help give her financial support while she is off work.Nicola Jackson has launched a fundraising page at GoFundMe to help the couple cope with the shortfall in maternity payment.On the page she said: I have set up this page to try and help my dear friend Kimberly and her family. Baby Rory is still in hospital  months on with no idea when he will be home and its heartbreaking to see them go through this. Kimberly writes on the fundraising page: Tuesday th June was just like any other day until that evening when my waters broke. I couldnt believe it would be my waters because I was just + weeks pregnant. Off to the hospital, it was confirmed to be my waters. The next day I got blue lighted to our closest level  hospitalI was told I would be here for the foreseeable until it was safe to deliver our baby.Well....  days later I got sepsis and become very poorly, very quickly so they had to deliver to save my le.After y conversations with all people involved, myself and Glenn, going against the doctors advice, our baby was delivered via classical section and me being put to sleep. I was just + weeks pregnant. He arrived + weeks early!!! Weighing g which is a tin and a half of tomatoes! title: mum 3 unrecognisable after spending
story: Mum-of- unrecognisable after spending £, to go under kne in Turkey on new bodyKim Irving, , flew to Turkey to undergo a gastric sleeve in  and went back in  to get a tummy tuck, a breast lt with fat injections and a mons ltKim Irving flew to Turkey on two separate occasions to undergo procedures to help her lose weight Image: @kimirving  CATERS NEWSByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsThis mum-of-three looks unrecognisable after spending £, on a new body.Kim Irving, , flew to Turkey to undergo a gastric sleeve followed by a aposmummy makeoverapos, which included a tummy tuck, a breast lt with fat injections and a mons lt. Kim, from Selby, North Yorks., now weighs nine stone and  pounds after previously tipping the scales at  stone.The makeup artist says she gained weight after getting a job in a Chinese takeaway as a teen and would get a free meal four times a week after work. Kim then went on to have three kids, Maddison, , Lily, , and Aiden, , in the space of four years. Kim, a makeup artist, added: I tried lots of diets and managed to lose two stone, however, I hit a wall and couldnapost lose anymore. So I decided to look into weight loss surgery, and I have never looked back. Iaposve shed over seven stone and I feel better than I have ever felt. However after losing weight, I still wasnapost happy with how my body looked. I still couldnapost wear all of the things I wanted to because of my loose skin. So I decided to go back to Turkey for the mummy makeover package. And I am so happy with my new body. Although I was big, I was never really miserable. I was just the fat and funny friend. Although I always had to shop in the plus-sized section of shops and I just got sick of it. I wanted to be able to buy the beautul dresses that I would see on Oh Polly and Pretty Little thing. And I felt a lot of pressure to look a certain way from working in the make-up industry because all of my clients are stunning. Kim says she chose a gastric sleeve procedure after doing research online. She says that the procedure cost her £.k compared to the cheapest UK price she found, which was £k. Kim said: The dference between the prices is crazy, it was a no brainer. I paid £ for my flights, and then in August , I boarded the plane with my husband and off I went.  I couldnapost wait to get it done because I had seen so many amazing before and after pictures. It was the first operation I had ever had but I knew it was going to be worth it. After ing home from Turkey, I lost  pounds in nine days. I couldnapost believe my eyes when I stepped on the scale, I nearly passed out. Two years after my weight loss surgery, Iaposd lost five stones and  pounds, not including the weight I had previously lost from dieting, and I felt amazing. However it was a mental battle to go from a size  to a size , and although I had lost so much weight I still didnapost feel like I could wear the clothes and swimwear Iaposd been dreaming of because I had a lot of loose skin. I knew I should have been happy because Iaposd lost lots of fat, but it still wasnapost quite right. So I started looking into plastic surgery and booked myself in for a trip back to Turkey for a mummy makeover and went under the kne again in September . The package included a tummy tuck, a breast lt with fat injections and a mons lt and cost £.k. I wasnapost nervous about the surgery, I just couldnapost wait to see the results. The hospital had taken such good care of me the first time, I wasnapost worried about it. Six weeks after her surgery, as the swelling went down, Kim started really noticing the results of her plastic surgery. She couldnapost wait to see her new stomach after hating the stretchy skin in that area so much. Kim said: When I first saw myself I couldnapost believe that it was my body I was looking at. My stomach was so tight and my belly button was perfect. I formed a shopping addiction because I couldnapost wait to try on clothes and bikinis, without having to worry about my loose skin or wearing hold-in underwear. I was getting clothes deliveries every day. I love my body now and I am filled with so much more confidence. Iaposll never have to go under the kne again. It feels amazing to be happy in my own body and be able to dress the way I have always wanted to. title: new omicron sub variant may
story: New Omicron sub-iant may outstrip existing version - all we know about BA.The Covid strain, named Omicron BA., has been identied more than  times in the UK since November, with cases multiplying in some parts of Europe and IndiaOmicron BA. has been classied as a iant under investigation Image: PAByDave BurkeSenior News Reporter:,  Jan | commentsA new Omicron iant may soon outpace its predecessor after more than  cases were found in the UK, scientists believe. The strain, named Omicron BA., has been identied more than  times in the UK since November, with cases multiplying in some parts of Europe and India. BA. was last week classied as a iant under investigation by the UK Health Security Agency . There are still huge gaps in our knowledge about the mutation, with early signs suggesting it could be even more transmissible than the dominant form of Omicron - known as BA. - but no more deadly. Worldwide data suggests that Denmark is currently the epicentre of the new iant, with more than , confirmed cases. But medics have said they do not believe there is cause for alarm, with new mutations always expected. Anders Fomsgaard, chief physician and virus researcher at the Statens Serum Institut , told Danish media: We cannot see any dference in hospitalization numbers, death rates with BA., so it is not something that worries us yet.”  He said that BA. is still a new piece in the Covid game, but continued: “Right now we should just treat it as yet another iant until new data should eventually show other results. Virologist Dr Tom Peacock, from Imperial College London, said he is confident that the new sub-iant is not a mixture of Delta and Omicron.He told the Daily Mail : Even with slightly higher transmissibility this absolutely is not a Delta to Omicron change, and instead is likely to be slower and more subtle.“That said, I would not be surprisedBA. slowly replaces [Omicron] over the coming months with a slightly more optimised mutations.apos The scientist, from Imperial College London, “Very early observations from India and Denmark suggest there is no dramatic dference in severity.” Authorities said  Omicron BA. infections have been confirmed by Whole Genome Sequencing in England, with the earliest dated December .The areas with the largest number of confirmed cases are Londonand the South East . It is not known where BA. first originated. So far  countries have uploaded more than , BA. sequences since mid-November. The first sequences were submitted from the Philippines and the highest number of samples have been uploaded from Denmark, where , cases have been found by Friday. Other countries that have uploaded more than  samples are India , Sweden , and Singapore . The UK Health Security Agencysays the emergence of new mutations is not unexpected.  Dr Meera Chand, COVID- Incident Director at UKHSA, said: “It is the nature of viruses to evolve and mutate, so it’s to be expected that we will continue to see new iants emerge as the pandemic goes on.Our continued genomic surveillance allows us to detect them and assess whether they are signicant. So far there is insufficient evidence to determine whether BA. causes more severe illness than Omicron BA., but data is limited and UKHSA continues to investigate. “Case rates remain high throughout the UK and we must remain vigilant and take up vaccinations. We should all continue to test regularly with LFDs and take a PCR testsymptoms develop”. In a statement, the UKHSA said: As is routine for any new iants under investigation, UKHSA is carrying out laboratory and epidemiological investigations to better understand the characteristics of this iant. We will continue to monitor this situation closely and recommend appropriate public health measuresneeded. More detail will be available in UKHSA’s regular Variant Technical Briefings. title: nursery accidentally ends out secret
story: Nursery accidentally sends out secret list of its worst mistakes to parentsWelcome Nurseries app inadvertently uploaded a document informing parents of list of faux pas it had made and posting it in information it publishes for parentsWelcome Nurseries run Smarties in Leicestershire - the management team has now changed though Image: BPM MEDIAByCorey BedfordGraeme Murray:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA nursery panicked parents by accidentally sending out a secret list of its most worrying mistakes. The internal document was posted on Welcome Nurseriesapos app and included a near escape, a boy getting stuck in the loo and a toddler left to sit with faeces on his leg. The company which owns Smarties in Enderby, Leicestershire, uses the app to keep parents up to date and inform them of any announcements.But it inadvertently uploaded a document informing parents of list of faux pas it had made, LeicestershireLive reports.It was quickly taken down and parents were informed it had been posted in error by a member of staff at the firmaposs head office. The biggest issue to emerge from the post was the fact that, in July , a child attending the West Street pre-school was found about to walk through a gate said to have been left open by a member of staff.  The company said a receptionist spotted the child thanks to the buildingaposs CCTV cameras and was able to intervene before the child walked through the gate and into the car park. A member of staff reported the incident to the then-manager and deputy manager. But it did not report the incident to the childaposs family, to head office or Ofsted, the company told The firm said head office was only made aware of the incident in early-January this year and had contacted the childaposs parents to inform them of what had happened. It says an investigation is ongoing into that and a number of other incidents - and a new management team is running the nursery now. They also acknowledged that staff members did not whistle-blow to superiors after realising the management had not reported the incident - with staff now retrained to report such issues in the future. A second issue mentioned in the letter admits that a pre-school boy was shut in the toilet for some time, leaving them visibly shaking and crying when let out.  The letter says the incident happened when a staff member was told to close the door to the bathroom to stop children running in and out. They did not check the cubicles to seeany children were on the toilet and this resulted in the boy being left behind the door. Welcome Nurseries said the door was accidentally closed while the child was in there, but when staff realised the he had not ed to the room, they went back to the bathroom and let him out. Other issues in the accidental post include reports of a staff member wiping babiesapos bottoms with antibacterial wipes instead of wet wipes, causing the babies to have sore, bleeding bottoms. A later investigation by the nursery did not support this allegation.  A cook was reported to have been left to supervise pre-school children alone with no qualications to do so, and a child in soiled nappy was left unattended for so long that faeces was stuck to his leg and took  minutes to remove. One parent whose child attends the nursery, who wishes to be anonymous, said: The entire post is very worrying, but my child attends the nursery section so I am particularly concerned that a member of staff was using antibacterial wipes on the babiesapos bottoms. I definitely havenapost been told about it and only found out due to the letter. We have to provide our own baby wipes so there was literally no excuse for them to use anything , they are completely dferent. They have covered staff mistakes up and we wouldnapost have known about itthe letter wasnapost posted. The nursery was already unreliable generally before this and had caused some concern, but hearing about a child escaping in the summer makes me worry , as a parent, will I find outmy child has been put at risk   A spokesperson for Welcome Nurseries has confirmed the management in charge of Smarties Nursery has changed since the incidents in question, and that the company was tackling the situation as a matter or urgency. An internal investigation is currently running to determine how and why the issues came about - including why the nurseryaposs management had not reported the issues to head office after being informed by staff members. The spokesperson said: We can confirm that we received an email of concern on the th January regarding alleged incidents that took place around July last year, under previous management. We can also confirm that we had no prior knowledge of the incidents until the email was sent to us. The safety and well-being of all our children are our number one priority and we immediately carried out a full investigation. It was alleged that a child managed to escape from the nursery into the car park. Whilst this allegation was unfounded, on investigation it was found that a gate was left open which was seen on CCTV by the receptionist, who acted immediately before the child went out of the gate. We also investigated further incidents which occurred around the same time in which a child was left in the bathroom on their own. Our investigation found that a child had entered the bathroom area and a member of staff not knowing he was there closed the door. Both incidents were reported to the previous management team who are no longer with the company, however these were not reported onward or investigated at the time. These incidents fall well below our standard of care and we have since retrained our staff. We are continuing to work with our parents and can assure all parents that we take all concerns seriously and act on them. We profusely apologise to all our children and parents that these incidents occurred and that we were not made aware of them sooner. We have not yet finished our investigations in this matter. We have a new management structure in place at the setting. We would also like to thank our parents for their continued support. A Leicestershire County Council spokesperson said: “We have very recently been made aware of concerns raised by a parent and will be working with the setting to ensure the appropriate procedures and policies are in place. news uk-news queen-couldnt-say-no-humiliating-"Royals take part in Its A Royal Knockout TournamentByZoe ForseyFeatures Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsThe Queenaposs motto that you need to be seen to be believed is something all the royal family live by, so theyaposre always keen to be involved in as many projects as possible. They attend royal engagements and travel the world on tours, meeting thousands of people every year. But sometimes, when a royal is starting to fall out of favour, they may do other bits and bobs in a bid to win fans over - with dfering levels of success. In June , Prince Edward, who organised the event, Princess Anne, Prince Andrew and Fergie went head-to-head in a special episode of Itaposs a Royal Knockout. Each royal had a team, which was representing a dferent charity, made up of celebrities, including the late Meat Loaf, who competed in a number of dferent events.However, it didnapost go quite as they hoped and has since been described as a disaster from start to finish and one of the biggest c***-ups in the royal familyaposs history. Royal expert Ben Pimlott claims the Queen didnapost like the idea at all and all of her staff believed it would be a mistake. An insider told him: [The Queen] was against it, but one of her faults is that she canapost say no. Recalling the show on Channel aposs Fergie Vs Diana:Royal Wives at War, royal expert Jennie Bond said: Itaposs a Royal Knockout will go down in royal history as one of the biggest c**k-ups of all time I think. It was a disaster from beginning to end, it was absolutely humiliating. Sarah with her usual gusto entered into it, andshe gets into something she does it with bells on. However not all of the royal family took up the offer of taking part.  Speaking on the documentary, the Daily Mailaposs Richard Kay said: Diana famously didnapost take part, neither did Charles. He thought it was something that was beneath them. In a way, itaposs kind of unfair, Fergie took a lot of the blame, almost the scapegoat. Her behaviour was being commented on and I think, then, is when Diana came into her own. The show, which was filmed at Alton Towers, was hosted by Stuart Hall, Les Dawson and Su Pollard. Paul Daniels acted as the chief referee. Princess Anneaposs red team, raising cash for Save the Children, included Tom Jones, Clf Richard, actress Jenny Agutter, and athlete Deborah Flintoff. Fergie was joined by Michael Brandon, Ben Cross and Jane Seymour, while Prince Andrewaposs World Wildle Team included Gary Lineker, Margot Kidder, Rhys Jones and John Travolta. Meat Loaf, who passed away this week, also took part. Prince Edward was in charge of the yellow team, raising cash for the Duke of Edinburgh Scheme. Among the celebs on his team were John Cleese, Eddie Grant, Peter Blake and Christopher Reeve. More than million people turned into watch it, making it the fourth most watched show of the year. However, it wasnapost all bad news as they at least managed to raise £.m for their chosen charities. news uk-news queen-jokes-theres-colour-never-"A look back at  years of the Queens glamorous fashionByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments While carrying out her royal duties, the Queen seems to have a work unorm of bright block colours.Whether itaposs bright orange, deep blue or shocking pink, her clothes are nothing short of eye-catching. But thereaposs one colour, youaposll rarely see the Queen wearing - and she once joked about the reason why. It appears that Her Majesty shuns wearing beige as it does nothing to help her stand out in a crowd - especially given her small stature. In his biography of the Queen, Robert Hardman says: My favourite remark she ever said was, aposI can ever wear beige because nobody will know who I am.’  And given the monarch has previously said she needs to be seen to be believed - it doesnapost seem she will be giving up bright colours any time soon.This was backed up by her daughter-in-law Sophie Wessex, who explained Her Majestyaposs colour palette in the documentary Our Queen at Ninety.Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. She explained: Donapost forget that when she turns up somewhere, the crowds are two, three, four, ten,  deep, and someone wants to be able to say they saw a bit of the Queenaposs hat as she went past. She needs to stand out for people to be able to say aposI saw the Queenapos.  The Queen is currently still enjoying her Christmas break after spending the festive season at Windsor Castle.However,  will be a huge year for Her Majesty, who will celebrate  years on the throne.Celebrations for her Plantinum Jubilee will include the -year-old monarch opening her private estates to the public and some of the worldaposs biggest stars performing outside Buckingham Palace. It is not clear which events she will attend or take part in as she was ordered to rest by doctors in October last year following an overnight hospital stay for unspecied preliminary investigations.The bulk of the Jubilee duties are thought likely to be given to the rest of the Royal Family, including the Prince of Wales and Duchess of Cornwall. The Queen usually spends the anniversary of her accession privately at Sandringham. news uk-news queen-s-prince-philips-cottage-"The Queen arrives at her Sandringham residenceByZoe ForseyFeatures Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsThe Queen has ed to Prince Philipaposs cottage for the first time since his death to mark the anniversary of her father, King George VI. She was pictured making the emotional pilgrimage from Windsor Castle to Sandringham in Norfolk on Sunday morning. She was driven part of the way and then took a helicopter.The couple lived apart in the final years of his le, with the Duke of Edinburgh based at Wood Farm while the Queen stayed at Buckingham Palace. She would regularly travel up to see him when she didnapost have engagements. The couple had only a small team of staff at the Farm, and they didnapost wear unorms as Philip didnapost like the formality. The five-bed cottage, which is tucked away on a quiet part of the estate overlooking the sea, is said to be were able to be a normal couple. The Queen is believed to have cooked and done the washing up during her stays there. Before Prince Philip moved in permanently, Wood Farm was regularly used by other members of the royal family. Kate Middleton stayed there during visits to the estate before she married Prince William. Itaposs also where Sarah Ferguson was made to stay after her orce from Prince Andrew. She wasnapost allowed to attend the Christmas celebrations in the aposBig Houseapos, but wanted to be nearby to see daughters Princesses Beatrice and Eugenie. Prince Philip lived alone with assistance from staff at Wood Farm on Sandringham estate after transforming it into a private retreat. He was said to enjoy his time there, tucked away from the other royals, reading, painting watercolours and having friends to stay. A source told Mail Online: Everything is being put in order for the Queenaposs visit,apos one said. aposWeaposve been told that she will stay at Wood Farm, rather than the main house, which is nice as that always had a special place in his heart. The Queen normally marks the tragic anniversary of her fatheraposs death at Sandringham, remaining there after the royal familyaposs Christmas break.  However the spike in Covid cases meant she decided against the traditional family vacation in , and instead spend the holiday at Windsor. February  will mark  year since the King passed away, aged just . It will be the first time the Queen marks the anniversary without Philip by her side. It was the Duke who told his we, then Princess Elizabeth, the devastating news of her fathersapos death. They were on holiday in Kenya at the time. The evening before, the Queen had been taking pictures of the incredible wildle from their tree top hideaway, including baboons, elephants and even a warthog.  The couple got ready to depart for the next stage of their tour, which should have also taken them to New Zealand and Australia. Back in England, at Sandringham, the Kingaposs staff were preparing to wake him for the day. Despite his recent bout of ill health, he had been happy the previous day and had even been on a shoot with a friend. His final acts were to play with his two grandchildren, Charles and Anne, and have dinner with his youngest daughter, Princess Margaret. James McDonald, the Kingaposs valet, realised something was seriously wrong with the monarch when he ran him a bath and he didnapost wake as he usually did. A doctor was called to the palace who confirmed the sad news that King George had passed away in his sleep. But the coupleaposs secluded and isolated location meant it was almost impossible to break the terrible news to the princess that her father was dead. Journalist Granville Roberts, who was covering the royal tour, was the first person to receive the news in Kenya.He immediately told Prince Philipaposs private secretary, Commander Michael Parker, who tuned into the BBC to confirm the news.The Duke of Edinburgh had been taking an afternoon nap and was stunned when he was woken told the sad news. And Prince Philip now had to work out how he would tell his we the tragic news that the father she adored had died and she was now Queen. Rather than tell his we in a formal setting, surrounded by their staff, Philip took her for a walk in the grounds of the lodge they were staying in. It was a private moment for the couple while Elizabeth could be alone with her husband during her moment of grief. Ever aware of her public duty, Elizabeth immediately discussed the practicalities of herto England. But she also asked for an hour alone in her room. The Queenaposswas delayed for several hours due to a storm. Her staff also realised her mourning outfit had already been sent on by plane to the next stop on her royal tour. title: real life cost soaring energy
story: Picture by Tim Merry" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _JS.jpg" width"" "" Diane Skidmores flat is too cold for her grandchildren to visit Image: Tim MerryByLucy ThorntonNews ReporterVikki WhiteFeatures Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsTemperatures have already plummeted to -C, with snow and further freezing conditions predicted across the country this week. And no one is feeling the cold - and the financial pinch - as much as pensioners. The Mirror is calling for VAT on energy bills to be scrapped as rocketing prices look set to push millions into poverty. The annual bill for an average three-bedroom gas-heated home could rise by an inflation-busting £ up to a huge £,, experts estimate. VAT of nearly % is included in what households pay for their gas and electricity. Scrapping it would save £ on the typical annual bill now, but could be worth £ a yeara price cap is hiked as expected in April. Here we reveal the harsh reality of rising energy costs faced by our elderly. Diane Skidmore,  Grandmother Diane Skidmore’s flat is so bitterly cold her grandchildren can’t even visit. The -year-old admits her home leaves all her visitors shivering and her family worried she’ll get pneumonia. But Diane says these are the s she has to go, to keep those rising energy bills down. The mum-of-six and gran to seven, has seen her energy bills soar by % in recent months from £ to £. Speaking from her frosty ground floor flat in Tulse Hill, South London, she said: “A neighbour came in yesterday and I noticed she was shivering. “I said ‘I’m really sorry. Let’s move into the living room’, where the temperature was not much dferent but the sun was shining in.”The former NHS worker gets £ to live on after her rent is paid from her state pension and is dreading the energy bill rises to come.“I live in the cold. My hands are freezing at the moment. Quite often my nose is cold like a dog’s. My kids are worried I will get pneumonia. “My daughters won’t bring the kids around because my house is so cold. They worry about me getting diseases or stuff too. “ Since the pandemic Diane only ventures out to get her prescriptions because she is asthmatic and has been shielding so does not spend any money on luxuries. “I’m very worried the bills are going up because I can’t live any more frugally than I already live,” she explained. “I already don’t turn the heating on most days and I never ever turn the heating on at night. “On the very coldest days I put it on at pm and put the kitchen timer on for half an hour. There is a cold patch around about pm. “I’ve got a bath but I don’t do that a lot to be honest. I’m very low maintenance. “I mostly eat vegetables. I’ve got a gas kettle because electric kettles take up so much energy. “I’m just worried it’s going to be horrible. I have to have faith. I’m not the only one with trouble going on, they have to come up with a solution.” Diane says she has tried other ways to heat her flat by blocking all the air vents and putting a big thick heavy curtain up but said it just causes condensation and black mould. “But I refuse to moan about it because when I was young we didn’t have gas central heating, when it got cold you just put a jumper on or do some exercise,” she said. But then admits: “At night it is very cold in here. “At the moment it’s only one degree at night and I can feel my head and my nose are absolutely verging on damp. I have to go down the bed under the sheets to get warm. “My old neighbour, who died, had a ‘noddy’ hat which he kept on all through winter. He used to sleep in it too. “Maybe I should get a hat.” Jack Mortimer,   Jack Mortimer was part of the ‘greatest generation’ during World War II, helping secure freedom for the world when he was just  years old and “frightened to death”. Regardless of these heroics the D-Day veteran, like many pensioners across the UK, is now living in fear of his energy bills. The -year-old only boils enough water for one cuppa and puts his immersion heating on every other day, to keep his rising energy bills down. At night the main light is switched off as he manages with his single bulb reading lamp only. And the energy “monitor thingy” he’s been given, sits ominously in the corner, constantly catching his eye. Jack has never been one to complain but says: “I don’t know how they can justy the increase. It doesn’t seem to be right but whatever Ofgem can do about it I don’t know. “I have always been economical with electricity. I only boil the amount of water you need for a cup of tea. Every other night I turn off the hot water system. “I have storage heaters and they are quite efficient and it’s cheap electric. “I am concerned the bills are going up because my income only goes up when the Government gives me a pension rise and as soon as they do that they take it off you in some other way. “Nobody seems to be worried about us. It’s like once you get over  they don’t want to know.” He lives alone in his third-floor flat in Leeds as his -year-old we Flo, who has dementia, went into a home last year. He visits her every day from  to pm. And while the couple are due to celebrate their th wedding anniversary next week, sadly they will not be together as they have both tested positive for Covid. His flat is all electric and he complained last year because he seemed to be paying more than his neighbours and a month ago was fitted with a smart meter. “They said I was paying more because I was not paying enough before and owed them nearly £. So I’m paying them in instalments now. These meters don’t seem to be as efficient as they should be,” he said. “I’ve had my meter changed now and yet to receive a new bill so I don’t know what dference that might make.”  He said out of his £ a week pension, he pays a £ monthly direct debit for his electric and pays a monthly rent of £. “I’m keeping my head above water but it is worrying,” he finally admits as he goes through his outgoings. “They have given me a monitor thingy to show how much I’m using. There’s an arc on it and it goes green when I’m doing all right but it goes in the red when I put the oven on. “When I’m sat at night, I don’t put the main bulb on which has three bulbs in it but just put the single light on, it’s not dangerous and is just enough light. “I only use the electric when I have to use it, when it gets dark I put a light on.” Jack was a despatch driver, behind the wheel of a jeep carrying ammunition and mortars on D-Day. He served with th Ordnance Beach Detachment. He landed on Sword Beach, as shells and mortars flew overhead, before advancing on to Caen. He said: “D-Day was a colossal project, you can’t imagine going over the Channel and being so close that you could almost step onto the next boat, there were thousands of them. “It was dangerous, there were snipers around. It was noisy and smoky when we landed, and I remember seeing lots of casualties. “I was  years old and frightened to death, everyone was, the army doesn’t tell you a lot, it gives you orders and you follow them, you don’t get an explanation. “...I was told to come off the beach and turn right, and there was a great big field which I helped to de-mine, then we dug a foxhole... and when you hear a plane approaching you jump straight into the foxhole. “I wouldn’t be here but for the paras who landed near Ranville - there were some big guns there and the paras took them out, otherwise Sword Beach could’ve been shelled out of existence. “ He got married to Flo after ing on leave in  and after the army became a General Manager of a clothing company in Halax making ladies’ blouses. He said previously: “I’m grateful that I’m alive, I’m grateful that I survived and I’m sorry that so many had to die, those were the heroes. “I don’t think I’m a hero, the heroes are the ones who didn’t come home, and they should always be remembered. It is very emotional, of course, to remember those who went and didn’t come back.” Pensioners queueing up for cafes to stay warm  Elderly people have been heading to a shopping centre in Leeds to keep warm and keep their heating bills down at home. At Denicos Italian cafe in Crossgates shopping centre in Leeds staff say some pensioners have been queuing up to come in from the cold - even before they open at .am. Waitress Leah Whitehouse said: “They come as soon as we open at .am. Every single morning. There are two people who sit for three hours and then come again in the afternoon.” Her colleague Tracy Smith, , adds: “They come to keep warm. It is sad and there are definitely more now.” One of their regulars Elizabeth Kumiskey,  and her -year-old husband, Peter, are in their favourite ‘warm spot’ in the middle of the cafe. They point out it’s much colder on the tables nearer the entrance. Former NHS nurse, Peter, explains how their gas was cut off before Christmas because there was a leak and their boiler was condemned. He said they can’t afford to get it fixed as it would take a massive “chunk” out of their savings which they were going to use for a walk-in shower to make it easier for them. “We got several quotes for the central heating and it was about £,. Even with grants offered. “We have savings but I want to keep those for Elizabeth. She is not on a full pension because she brought up five children. It’s an insult what they get! “If I go first I want to leave something for her.” Putting a brave face on their predicament, he adds: “We’ve got a couple of electric fans now so it’s a bit better and we put the snake draft excluder down. We don’t have enough hot water for a bath. “We save money by buying food here. It’s cheaper than buying groceries and putting the oven on and it’s nice.” Elizabeth, clutching her mug of coffee for warmth and wearing a woolly bobble hat, added: “I keep warm when Peter holds my hand.” And about the sacrices they have made to pay their bills, she adds: “You just expect less. We are quite frugal. We would like to go on holiday for a few days, somewhere with a bath maybe.” At a nearby Age UK meeting Margaret Logan, , a former supermarket worker, says she also watches the energy she uses carefully as she pays around £ a quarter. She said: “I don’t have the heating on high just to warm the room a bit. I try not to cook as much with the electric cooker and use my microwave instead. “I like to go out a couple of times a week for a coffee but when the prices go up I might have to stop that.” She adds: “But I’m not too bad. I’m lucky. “The other day I went round to see my friend and she was sat in her big thick coat to keep warm. It was so cold in her house. She had no money because she had bought Christmas presents for her family members”. Jacqueline Lawson, the Leeds coordinator for Age UK, said some pensioners have been putting newspapers to block the drafts in their windows. She added: “I know people who have not been out for two years because of the pandemic so their house is a sanctuary for them. But when they are frightened of putting the heating on - that sanctuary ends up a cold and hostile place. It becomes a cold fridge.” Coldest town in England  It’s the coldest place ever recorded in England. In January , temperatures in Newport, Shropshire, plunged to -. degrees. So where better to talk to people about the impending energy crisis  We bump into Philip and Pat Briscoe, who have been married for  years, on the market town’s main thoroughfare. “We were with Avro,” explained Pat, , speaking of one of the energy firms which collapsed last year, with Ofgem appointing Octopus Energy to take over. “That was last September, so we’ve gone over to Octopus but we don’t know what our rate’s going to be yet. They’ve got too many to deal with so they keep sending us emails telling us we will be able to look at our account soon. “We are concerned but we’re fortunate that we can afford to pay,” added the former receptionist. “If it doubles we will cut down a bit.” “We have to becauseyou pay more for your heating you’re going to be paying more for your food as well,” said Philip, . “Everything’s going up at the moment.” Brian and Celia Styles feel for people who are struggling. “You’re bound to get a higher bill anyway because it’s the winter,” said Celia, . “And until it comes you just don’t know how much. Financially we’re not that bad but a lot of people will struggle. The cost of living and everything’s going up. A lot of people,they’ve lost their jobs, where are they going to get the money from ” “It’s going to go up whatever happens,” added Brian, an -year-old retired industrial engineer. “I just put the heating onI need it but not everyone can do that.” Many older people suggested young people were suffering the most. “I think my monthly bills will go up by %,” said Judy, , a former PA in education. “My electricity is with E.ON and they’ve told me it needs to go up, I’m still waiting on the gas. “You either use the gas or you’re cold which I’m not prepared to be. “The problem is everything has gone up, including food,” she added. “I feel for people who can’t afford the increase - clothing, heating, food, everything’s going up. A lot of people are in poverty now. It’s an awful situation where you have heat or eat. “I feel most sorry for the families just above the limit where they can get help.” “I’m glad I’m at the end and not the beginning,” said Judy as she headed off to finish her shopping. “I feel for my grandchildren. Where are we heading ” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON OfgemOctopus EnergyAge UKEnergy billsMental health" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: savvy student couple save thousands
story: Savvy student couple save thousands living in van to dodge expensive university rentDaniel Dayment spent £, kitting out his Citroen Relay van with a double bed, a toilet and a mini kitchen to avoid paying for university accommodationDaniel Dayment with Mary Cullen in their converted Citroen Relay van  Image: Daniel Dayment Mercury PressByJade CulverAntony Thrower:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A couple have saved thousands of pounds in living expenses by kitting out a van with a toilet, a hob and a double bed in a bid to avoid paying out on expensive student accommodation.Daniel Dayment, , spent £, on the van conversion after saving up money at university from odd jobs including freelance photography, cleaning, and working in a bike shop, as well as saving part of his student loan. Daniel, a third-year photography student, and his partner, Mary Cullen, , who live in Totnes, Devon, spent three months converting the  Citroen Relay van as a lockdown project over the summer of . Living in a van allows them to save more than £, on rent and utility bills each year.Have you got an unusual living situation  Email webnews@mirror to tell your story Daniel said: It was always my plan to have my own home by my third year of university, specically a home that was minimalist and one that I could travel around in. I saved up the money to convert a van, as I didnapost want to pay the high rent of a student flat for a year. It would have cost me £ alone just to live in student accommodation for ten months. Having a converted van is really a future financial asset to me now, Iaposm saving money by not having to spend it on bills or extortionate accommodation rent.  Mary, a freelance graphic designer, added: Before I met Daniel, I never thought about living in a van but itaposs just so convenient and thereaposs so many adventures that we have yet to plan. I miss having a toaster, as we have to fry our toast, but I have really come to enjoy van le and when living on the road, you come to realise you donapost need the same electrical appliances most households canapost go without. The Plymouth College of Art student first purchased his van for £, in March , and spent a further £, on renovations, including a £ eco-friendly solar electrical system. The van boasts a hob to cook on, storage for clothes and food, a compost toilet, a kitchen counter and even a double bed to make for a cosy home on wheels.  Daniel said: The batteries and solar electrical system were probably the most expensive part of the renovation, but it was worth the money as it was the price of what someone would spend a year on their electrical bills. To light the van, I got some fairy lights and LED lights to make it look homely, they were £ and really light up the small space. I managed to get a second-hand Welsh dresser for £ that I broke down and converted into the kitchen counter where I store the pots and pans. I also created a compost toilet for £ from scrap pieces of wood, a bucket, and iders for solids and liquids. It might sound weird, but the toilet is my favourite part of the renovation. I use a coconut peat, and a vinegar solution to neutralise the smells and as itaposs compostable, itaposs all very environmentally friendly. One the most luxury items in the van is the l camper fridge that cost £, itaposs usually cool enough to hold ice cream which is a nice treat. Daniel used scrap wood to create the bed with room for storage underneath, as well as adding a food cupboard and hooks for to the inside of the van for coffee mugs. Everything inside of the van is multipurpose, with seating including a storage box and the compostable toilet. Despite enjoying the simplicities of van le, the couple have had to make a series of compromises in order to live on the road. Mary said: We both kind of miss hot running water, so we have to shower at campsites and use laundrettes when travelling. Iaposm a notorious clothes hoarder, so when I moved into the van with Daniel, I had to cull a lot of things, only to realise I never really needed them anyway. Daniel continued: Van le is all about improvising and doing things that may not be considered the norm. Van le allows you to be as low impact and eco-friendly as possible whilst being able to travel as much as you like.The couple have plans to travel through Europe once most Covid- restrictions are lted and Daniel finishes university.The price breakdown The Van,  Citroen Relay MWB £, Paint for the outside of the van £ Interior wood, Ply and Cladding £ Roof rack £ Insulation £ Windows £ Roof vent fan £ Swivel chair base £ Solar  and charge controller £ Batteries £ Battery to battery charger £ Fridge £ Mattress £ Wiring £ Led Lights £ Fairy lights £ Diesel heater £ Compost toilet £ Second hand welsh dresser £ Sink and tap £  burner hob £ Tools for the build £ Endless trips to screwfix £ Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON CitroenEducationStudents" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news travel-boost-families-kids--"Spain: British expat questions enforcement of Covid passesByMatthew DreschNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsChildren aged  to  are set to be granted Covid travel passes, making holidays far easier for UK families, according to reports.Parents are currently forced to ring up NHS  or go online to request an NHS Covid Pass letter for hassle-free holidays to popular destinations such as Spain, Italy and France. From Monday British teenagers will be able to download a digital Covid pass through the NHS app or the official website, The Sun reports.It will allow youngsters to avoid quarantines and self-testing rules when they land overseas. Testing is also reportedly set to be dropped for vaccinated Brits coming back to the UK from next month in a double boost for the travel industry, the newspaper adds.The changes will make le a lot easier for families travelling to Europe as venues in France, Switzerland, Greece, Germany, Austria and Cyprus demand either proof of vaccination, a negative Covid test or evidence of recovery from the virus for children aged over . This is dferent to the UK, where under-s are exempt from showing Covid passes. A source told the Daily Mail that the changes will help families avoid an aposadministrative nightmareapos. However, unvaccinated travellers will still need to undergo a test upon ing to Britain.It comes as Boris Johnson prepares to drop Plan B restrictions next week.  Compulsory Covid passes for large venues will be axed from January  as the rules are set to expire in law at the end of January , the Prime Minister told MPs. People will also no longer need to wear masks in shops and on public transport when the regulations expire. We will continue to suggest the use of face coverings in enclosed or crowded places, particularly where you come into contact with people you don’t normally meet, Mr Johnson previously said. But we will trust the judgement of the British people and no longer criminalise anyone who chooses not to wear one. The Government is also no longer asking people to work from home. Mr Johnson previously said: Todayaposs latest ONS data shows infection levels are falling in England and while there are some places where cases are likely to continue rising, including in primary schools, our scientists believe it is likely that the Omicron wave has peaked nationally. The PM said England couldto Plan A and allow the remaining restrictions to expire. news uk-news uk-weather-forecast-brits-blasted-"UK weather: Met Office forecasts dry and cloudy conditionsByWilliam WalkerNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments After temperatures plummeted as low as -C overnight an Arctic blast is predicted to freeze the nation in the coming weeks with days of snow forecast.The whole of the UK shivered in sub zero temperatures over the weekend and Wales recorded its coldest night of the winter.The Met Office said the nation froze as the mercury dropped to -C on Friday.And then the temperatures dropped even further with more than -C recorded over the weekend. Now, the Met Office is warning of ‘severe frost’ and icy conditions for the start of the week on Monday with a deep freeze set to sweep across England and Wales.  And snow could fall in Scotland as well as parts of northern England from Thursday. Long range predictions by the Met Office also state that snow might fall in northern regions from early February as the freezing temperatures continue. Before then, on Monday, forecasters predict that in the south it will remain cold but with the promise of brighter intervals, with similar conditions in the north, Scotland and Northern Ireland.  For Tuesday and Wednesday there will be occasional rain in the northwest which will move south on Thursday, bringing potentially heavy showers.The coldest weather will begin from Thursday onwards.A spokesman for the Met Office said: It will turn very briefly colder on Thursday and as conditions move south it will bring showers with it.  Across England and Wales it will remain largely dry for the week, there will be more in the western areas of Scotland. But forecasters said the chance of widespread snow this week was not expected, and flurries would largely stay on higher parts of Scotland. UK Weather Forecast Today: Cold and cloudy but dry for most areas today. A few bright or sunny spells are likely in some areas, mainly eastern Scotland, northeast England and, perhaps, parts of Wales. Thicker cloud will bring northern Scotland rain at times. Tonight: Most areas remaining cold and cloudy tonight, cloud over parts of northern Scotland thick enough for some rain at times. Tuesday: Another cloudy day follows on Tuesday, cloud over northern Scotland thick enough for some rain, mainly later. Probably a few breaks in the east. Feeling cold. Outlook for Wednesday to Friday: Changeable largely dry for most, any rain predominantly affecting western coasts and hills, especially the Highlands and Islands. Breezy, with risk of gales in the far north at times. Mild. news uk-news uk-weather-forecast-just-three-"UK weather: Met Office forecasts dry and cloudy conditionsByAntony Thrower:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsBrits are being warned to pack an umbrella later this week as rain showers are set to surge across the country.The Met Office says the country is set to remain dry for the first half of the coming week, before a soggy end.Tonight is going to be mostly cloudy, although breaks in that may mean people wake up to a frosty start in the morning. Later on Monday in the south it will remain cold but with the possible promise of brighter intervals, with similar conditions in the north, Scotland and Northern Ireland. For Tuesday and Wednesday there will be occasional rain in the northwest which will move south on Thursday, bringing potentially heavy showers. A spokesman for the Met Office said: “It will turn very briefly colder on Thursday and as conditions move south it will bring showers with it.  “Across England and Wales it will remain largely dry for the week, there will be more in the western areas of Scotland.” Brits worried about the possibility of the arrival of snow can relax however as it is not expected this week. He added: “There could be some in the highest ground of Scotland on some of the mountains. “Nothing  wintry is expected at all.” It comes as  was officially named the joint sixth warmest year since records began  years ago.  The Met Office warned global warming and other long-term climate change trends are expected to continue as a result of record levels of heat-trapping greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. Dr Colin Morice, of the Met Office, said: “ is one of the warmest years on record, continuing a series of measurements of a world that is warming under the effects of greenhouse gas emissions. This extends a streak of notably warm years from  to  - the warmest seven years in over  years of measurements.”  Prof Tim Osborn, of the University of East Anglia, added: “Each year tends to be a little below or a little above the underlying long-term global warming. “Global temperature data analysed by the Met Office and UEAaposs Climatic Research Unit show  was a little below, while  had been a little above, the underlying warming trend. “All years, including , are consistent with long-standing predictions of warming due to human activities.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Met OfficeUniversity of East AngliaSnowClimate changeWeather" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates from our environment editor on green issues and actions you can takeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: witness claims madeleine mccann suspect
story: Witness claims Madeleine McCann suspect was with her before and after disappearanceThe German witness, who was living in Portugal in , believes Christian Brueckner was miles away from Praia da Luz in Portugal on the day Madeleine McCann went missing from a resort thereChristian Brueckner, the prime suspect Image: REX ShutterstockByMartin FrickerNews ReporterDanya BazaraaSenior News Reporter:,  Jan A new witness has come forward in the case of missing Madeleine McCann claiming to have been with the prime suspect just before and after she disappeared, it is reported. The new witness reportedly insists Christian Brueckner was calm while she was with him and says they were stopped by police who reported no suspicious activity. The German witness, who was living in Portugal in , believes Brueckner was miles away from Praia da Luz in Portugal on the day Madeleine went missing from a resort there. A source told the Sun: She says she was not with him the day Madel­eine disappeared but spoke with him and again said he seemed normal. The source said: This ­testimony could be an issue.  This comes just days after German journalists who were investigating the case claimed they have uncovered “shocking” evidence which “heavily incriminates” Brueckner. British youngster Madeleine was just three-years-old when she vanished from her parents’ holiday apartment in Portugal in . German prosecutors claim to have evidence she is dead and named convicted paedophile Christian Brueckner as their only suspect. Despite going public with the information in June , they have still not charged him with any offence.  But now a team working for TV channel Sat. have handed the evidence to detectives probing Brueckner over the infamous case. Sat. investigators claim to have found fresh evidence linking Brueckner, who denies any involvement, to the crime. They will reveal more information about their investigation in a prime-time documentary, which is yet to have an air date. Announcing the show, Sat. said journalist Jutta Rabe and a team of reporters gathered new information about Brueckner. They claim it includes proof he was near Praia da Luz when Madeleine vanished while her parents dined in a tapas restaurant. The channel said they collected “many new clues and indications” that corroborate the suspicions of German prosecutors.Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Christian BMadeleine MccannMissing persons" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you.
